questions.text:
Which of the following statements about diverticulitis is incorrect?


	Diverticulitis often presents with abdominal pain localized to the lower left side.
	A barium enema is a preferred imaging method for diagnosing diverticulitis.
	Colostomy is often performed as a first-line treatment.
	Stage Ib of the Modified Hinchey Classification refers to a pericolic abscess.
	Complications of diverticulitis may include fistula formation, such as colovesical fistula.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 2 and 3

 

Explanation:

Diverticulitis

Definition
  • Inflammation or infection of diverticula in the colon.

Etiology
  • Obstruction (fecal matter or food): Trapped fecal matter or food causes pressure and inflammation.
  • Bacterial infection: Infection occurs when bacteria proliferate in obstructed diverticula.

Pathophysiology
  • Increased pressure from trapped fecal matter can lead to inflammation, infection, and sometimes perforation of the diverticula.

Symptoms
  • Abdominal pain (lower left side) (Statement 1 ruled out)
  • Fever
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Change in bowel habits (diarrhea or constipation)
  • Tenderness on examination

Diagnosis
  • CT Scan (IOC): Preferred for detailed imaging of the colon, identifying inflammation and abscesses.
  • Ultrasound: Can detect inflammation and abscesses, but less detailed than CT.
  • Blood Tests: Elevated white blood cell count suggests infection or inflammation.
  • Barium Enema (contraindicated) (Statement 2): Should be avoided as it can worsen symptoms.

Management
  • Antibiotics
  • Pain management (analgesics)
  • Dietary modifications (clear liquids, then low-fiber, high-fiber)
 

Surgery (for severe cases or complications)

  • Resection: Removal of the affected segment of the colon to treat severe diverticulitis or complications.
  • Colostomy (Statement 3): Creation of an abdominal opening for waste elimination, often used in severe cases.
  • Drainage of Abscesses: Percutaneous or surgical methods to drain abscesses associated with diverticulitis.

Modified Hinchey Classification (Severity of acute diverticulitis)
  • Stage 0: Mild diverticulitis
  • Stage I:
    • Ia: Pericolic inflammation
    • Ib: Pericolic abscess (Statement 4 ruled out)
  • Stage II: Pelvic or intra-abdominal abscess
  • Stage III: Purulent peritonitis
  • Stage IV: Fecal peritonitis

Complications
  • Hemorrhage (painless and profuse)
  • Perforation (can cause pericolic abscess)
  • Intestinal Obstruction (large or small bowel)
  • Fistula Formation (e.g., colovesical) (Statement 5 ruled out)
  • Leads to frequent UTIs, fecaluria, pneumaturia

questions.text: Which variant of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis is associated with both colorectal cancer and brain tumors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Turcot Syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • Turcot syndrome is associated with both colorectal cancer and brain tumors.

 

Variants of FAP:

 

Classic FAP (Option A)

Most common form with extensive polyps

Attenuated FAP (Option B)

Milder form with fewer polyps

Gardner syndrome (Option C)

Classic FAP + additional tumors

Turcot syndrome (Option D)

FAP variant with brain tumor

 

Gardner Syndrome

Turcot Syndrome
  • Autosomal dominant variant
  • Autosomal recessive variant

Associated with

  • Osteoma
  • Congenital Hypertrophy of retinal Pigment Epithelium(CHRPE)
  • Desmoid tumor
  • Epidermoid cyst
  • Supernumerary teeth
  • Benign lymphoid polyposis of ileum
  • Sebaceous cyst

Associated with brain tumors in both FAP and lynch syndrome

  • In FAP, causes Medulloblastoma.
  • In lynch syndrome, causes Glioblastoma multiforme.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent colorectal cancer. Her family history reveals that her mother was diagnosed with endometrial cancer at age 50, and her aunt had ovarian cancer. Genetic testing is recommended. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lynch Syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in the above clinical scenario is Lynch syndrome/Hereditary Non Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC)
  • Autosomal dominant condition caused by inherited mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6 and PMS2) which code for mismatch repair protein (MMR) leading to microsatellite instability.
  • Endometrial cancer, Ovarian cancer and increased risk of stomach, intestinal cancers.

 

Amsterdam II Criteria
  • Three or more family members with Lynch syndrome related cancer, one of whom is a 1° relative.
  • Two or more successive affected generations.
  • At least one tumor diagnosed before 50 years.
  • FAP excluded

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with multiple oral papillomas, facial trichilemmomas, and a history of thyroid nodules. She also reports that her mother had breast cancer at a young age. On examination, multiple small, wart-like growths on her hands is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cowden disease

 

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in the above case scenario is Cowden disease.

 

Cowden disease / Multiple Hamartomas:

  • Loss of PTEN function leads to activation of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway, promoting cell proliferation and survival.
  • Clinical manifestations such as Hamartomas, Trichilemmomas, papillomatous papules, and acral keratoses, Oral papillomas, Multinodular goiter, adenomas.

 

 

Patients need to have two major criteria to be diagnosed with Cowden disease. (One of the two must be either Lhermitte-Duclos disease or macrocephaly.)

  • Lhermitte-Duclos disease
  • Thyroid carcinoma
  • Macrocephaly
  • Breast cancer

Treatment: Surveillance, Removal of symptomatic hamartomas or cancers and Cutaneous lesion treated with surgical excision and 5-fluorouracil.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal distension along with tenderness. X-ray shows dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels. The patient is taken for exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following structures is most likely to be visualized first to differentiate between small intestine and large intestine obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cecum

Explanation:

  • The cecum, located in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, is the first part of the large intestine and is typically the first structure visualized during surgery for suspected intestinal obstruction.
  • It helps in differentiating between small and large intestine obstructions:
    • Dilated cecum: Indicates a large bowel obstruction, as it is proximal to the blockage.
    • Collapsed cecum with dilated small intestines: Suggests a small bowel obstruction.
  • Identifying the cecum first allows surgeons to accurately determine the obstruction site and guide appropriate surgical management.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain, distension, and constipation. A CT scan reveals a large intestinal obstruction at the level of the descending colon. Which of the following arteries is primarily responsible for providing collateral circulation in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Marginal Artery of Drummond

 

Explanation:

  • Marginal artery of Drummond is primarily responsible for providing collateral circulation in intestinal obstruction.

 

Anatomy of the Large Intestine

 

Segments:

 

Blood supply of the Large Intestine

Arterial Supply
  • Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA):
    • Supplies the cecum, ascending colon, and proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon. (Option A)
  • Inferior Mesenteric Artery (IMA):
    • Supplies the distal one-third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum. (Option B)
  • Marginal Artery of Drummond:
    • An important arterial anastomosis running along the inner border of the colon, connecting branches of the SMA and IMA, ensuring continuous blood supply and providing collateral circulation. (Option C)
  • Arc of Riolan / Meandering mesenteric artery:
    • It is a collateral branch running close to the mesentery, connecting superior mesenteric artery to inferior mesenteric artery.
    • It also connects proximal part of middle colic artery to left colic artery (Option D)


 

Venous Drainage

Blood from the colon drains into the superior mesenteric vein and inferior mesenteric vein, which then drain into the portal vein leading to the liver.

Lymphatic Drainage

Lymph from the colon drains into the mesenteric lymph nodes and ultimately into the thoracic duct.

questions.text:
Assertion: The colon plays a significant role in the production of short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) from dietary fibers.

Reason: Fermentation of dietary fibers by gut bacteria in the colon produces SCFAs like butyrate, acetate, and propionate, which serve as metabolic fuel for colon cells.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.
The Assertion is true, but the Reason is false.
Both Assertion and Reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.

 

Explanation:

Physiological functions of the colon

 

Function

Description

Water and Electrolyte Absorption
  • Absorbs water, sodium (Na+), and chloride (Cl-) to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.

Secretion
  • Secretes potassium (K+), bicarbonate (HCO3-), and mucus to protect mucosa and facilitate fecal passage.

Fermentation and SCFA Production
  • Ferments dietary fibers to produce short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) like butyrate, acetate, and propionate, which serve as metabolic fuel for colon cells.
  • The right colon, particularly the cecum, is the primary fermentation site. (Option A)

Storage and Dehydration of Stool
  • The left colon stores fecal matter and absorbs water to form solid stools.

Vitamin Production
  • Gut bacteria synthesize vitamins such as vitamin K and some B vitamins, which are absorbed by the colon.

Protection and Immunity

Provides a barrier against pathogens through mucus, epithelial tight junctions, and immune cells.

Motility and Transit
  • Exhibits peristaltic movements to mix contents and move them toward the rectum.
  • Mass peristalsis propels fecal matter for defecation.

Regulation of pH
  • Absorbs SCFAs and secretes bicarbonate to maintain optimal pH for bacterial activity and colonic function.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension, vomiting, and failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended, and a digital rectal examination reveals a tight anal sphincter with an explosive discharge of stool upon withdrawal of the finger. What is the best step of investigation to confirm the exact pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rectal biopsy

 

Explanation:

  • Rectal biopsy is the investigation of choice for Hirschprung’s disease.

 

Hirschsprung's Disease

 

Introduction

Congenital disorder known as congenital aganglionic megacolon or aganglionosis.

Pathophysiology

CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Neonates:
  • Failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours.
  • Abdominal distension.
  • Bilious vomiting

Infants and Children
  • Chronic constipation
  • Poor feeding
  • Failure to thrive
  • Enterocolitis (fever, diarrhea, and abdominal distension)

DIAGNOSIS

Clinical Evaluation

History and physical examination indicating chronic constipation and failure to pass meconium.

Radiological

Abdominal X-ray: Shows dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels. (Option A)
 

Contrast (Barium) Enema: Demonstrates a transition zone between dilated proximal and narrow distal bowel. (Option B)

Rectal Biopsy

Gold standard and IOC for diagnosis, showing the absence of ganglion cells. (Option C)

Anorectal Manometry

Shows lack of rectoanal inhibitory reflex. (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent chest pain and difficulty swallowing. He gives a history of gastrointestinal discomfort and was recently diagnosed with both hiatal hernia and diverticulosis during a routine endoscopic examination. Given his current history, what is the other condition that has the highest probability for which he should be evaluated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gallstones

 

Explanation:

  • The given condition is suggestive of Saint’s triad, therefore, gallstones should be evaluated.
  • Saint's triad is a rare clinical syndrome that includes the following three conditions:
    1. Hiatal hernia: A condition where part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm muscle.
    2. Diverticulosis: The presence of diverticula in the colon.
    3. Gallstones: Solid particles that form from bile cholesterol and bilirubin in the gallbladder.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with symptoms of abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits. A barium enema is performed, which reveals a characteristic finding on imaging given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diverticulosis

Explanation:

  • The given image shows saw tooth appearance indicating Diverticulosis.

Diverticulosis

Definition
  • Presence of small, bulging pouches (diverticula) in the colon, most commonly in the sigmoid colon.

Symptoms
  • Often asymptomatic; may include mild abdominal discomfort, bloating, and changes in bowel habits.

Diagnosis

(Option A)
  • Colonoscopy: Direct visualization.
  • CT Scan: Detailed images of the colon.
  • Barium enema: Less common, show a characteristic sawtooth appearance

 

Colon Cancer (Option B):

  •  On Barium enema Apple core appearance/napkin ring-like lesions are seen.

Pseudomembranous colitis (Option C):

  • In CECT, Accordion sign can be seen

Ischemic colitis (Option D):

  •  On barium enema or plain x-ray, Thumb-print sign (characteristic sign) is seen.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly identifies a type of non-neoplastic polyp?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Juvenile polyp

 

Explanation:

 

﻿Classification of Colorectal Polyps

 

Neoplastic Polyps

Non-Neoplastic Polyps

Adenomatous Polyps (Adenomas)

  • Tubular (Option A)
  • Villous (Option D)
  • Tubulovillous

Inflammatory Polyps

  • Associated with inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)

Serrated Polyps

  • Hyperplastic Polyps
  • Sessile Serrated Adenomas (SSA/Ps) (Option B)
  • Traditional Serrated Adenomas (TSAs)

Hamartomatous Polyps

  • Juvenile Polyps: Usually in children, generally benign but associated with Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome. (Option C)
 
  • Peutz-Jeghers Polyps: Associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, characterized by pigmentation around the mouth.
 

Lymphoid Polyps

  • Composed of lymphoid tissue, usually benign and associated with the immune response

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with intermittent abdominal pain, occasional rectal bleeding, and pigmented macules on her lips, buccal mucosa, and digits. Her mother had similar pigmented spots. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome

 

Explanation

  • The most likely diagnosis of the above condition is Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome.
  • Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome is caused by mutations in the STK11 (LKB1) gene located on chromosome 19p13.3.
  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: 
    • Intermittent abdominal pain due to intussusception or obstruction by polyps, rectal bleeding, iron-deficiency anemia.
  • Mucocutaneous Pigmentation:
    • Dark blue to dark brown macules on the lips, buccal mucosa, and digits, Pigmented lesions may also appear around the eyes, nostrils and anus

  • Cancer Risks:
    • ​​​​​​​Increased risk of gastrointestinal, pancreatic, breast, ovarian, cervical, and testicular cancers

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to rectal bleeding. His father died of colon cancer at age 40. Colonoscopy reveals hundreds of polyps throughout the colon. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)

 

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in the above condition is FAP ( familial adenomatous polyposis)

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP):

  • Caused Autosomal dominant mutation in the APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) gene on chromosome 5q21.
  • 100% risk of colorectal cancer in those with APC gene mutation.
  • 80% cases are from positive family history.
  • Numerous (>100) colorectal adenomatous polyps, typically developing in adolescence or early adulthood

 

Diagnosis:

  • Colonoscopy showing >100 polyps and biopsy showing adenomatous variety of polyp.
